text:
Hi, everybody. I'm Stevie. Like Michael said, I'm
an assistant professor. I'm a newer professor at
University of Minnesota.

So it's A, great to be here. And B, great to be
in a place where I don't have to wear a puffer
that goes down to my knees

to walk between buildings. And so today, I'm going to
talk to you about the work that I do in human-centered
AI for mental health

prediction on social media. Before I get
started though, I do have to warn you
and the audience that because of the work
I do on mental health,

I'm going to be
talking about subjects related to mental health
with some examples in this presentation.

Specifically, I'm going to be
talking about and discussing examples in the most general
cases related to suicide as well

as to eating disorders. There is one example
towards the end of the talk that is a
specific tweet of somebody who

is thinking about
ending their own life. If you need to go
take a walk or not pay attention during
that portion of the talk,

I totally understand. I don't know the
difference between you need to take a bathroom break
and you need to just take a walk for your own well-being.

I encourage it if
that's something that's important to you. So let's go ahead
and get started. At this point of my
career, most of us

are aware that there
is a mental health crisis in the United States. About one in five
people in the US in 2021

reported experiencing
mental illness. And that would be
what we consider like a clinically relevant
level of distress and disorder.

And then in that same time
period, one in 20 in the US experienced severe
mental illness.

Something that therapists and
clinicians and psychiatrists would really want
to intervene in. Something that's like
dramatically affecting people's

lives and well-being. And of those people, nearly
50,000 people in the US die by suicide every year.

This number is way up
from historical averages. This has gone up
noticeably since 2010.

But that may seem
big or small to you just kind of depending on the
context of which you understand

mental health. But one of the most
troubling parts about this is about 12 million adults
seriously think about suicide

every year. And those are the kind of people
that many times our clinical as well as sort of therapeutic
interventions cannot reach

because they are
suffering in silence. So people go online
to try and communicate about their well-being
to talk to others,

but also to reach out to
trusted family and friends to try and get information
about mental health

and to help them
just feel better. So I've been studying
this work since about-- or the work on mental
health since about 2014.

2018, 2019, social
media companies started rolling
out AI systems that would allow them to
detect when people

were talking about what I
call severe or dangerous mental illness. This is when someone's
talking about things

that involve physical or bodily
harm like suicidal thoughts or self-injury.

And part of the
motivation behind this is for interventions
for content moderation. But other platforms like
Facebook, in this case,

actually were trying to use
it for prevention efforts. So in 2018, Facebook
deploys this algorithm

behind the scenes
that helps them identify when somebody
may be thinking about ending their own life.

They say it's run at the time
by a random forest model based on text patterns in data. If you're familiar
with this, this

is actually a
pretty lightweight, easy, straightforward model. And they say that this
model was able to get

about 10 people every day
that weren't already reported by friends and family on the
platform for an intervention.

And Facebook says that they use
this model to help identify when an intervention
might be necessary

such as sending people
information about hotlines or trusted support or connecting
them with resources to help them

work through whatever
they're going through. And it's not just
Facebook that has these models on the back end. Google X slash Twitter,
Reddit, a lot of companies

actually have these
kind of models both for content
moderation reasons as well as being supportive
of people who are in distress.

And so I think that these
models and this deployment ask some really interesting
questions about building

AI to detect this. And so I like to
think about this in terms of the consequences
of what happens when we

make a bad system to predict-- suicidal ideation, or some
other kind of mental illness.

And the challenge
here is like building bad systems in this case
have technical consequences.

It's bad models. We just get bad
scientific standards. Our performance kind of stinks.

We don't represent the
concepts that we want to and so we don't
actually intervene in the appropriate
situation because we've

gotten the answer wrong. And I think that
there's a lot of risks here about what might happen
if you have a poor model that

predicts suicidal
ideation or depression or any number of
mental illnesses.

And then one of the
things I wanted to mention is that a lot of my
past work actually worked on building
better models for this.

So during my PhD, I spent a lot
of time trying to engineer ways that you can infer that somebody
might actually be suffering

from elevated
levels of distress, and then thinking about the
consequences of building that. So this is two systems that
I worked on for my PhD.

One of these is a multimodal
representation of Tumblr data where we were able to take in
the image as well as the text

data that came along
with this, and then be able to predict whether
or not it was severe enough that something might be taken
down or require an intervention.

Another one we built
was assessing people's mental illness severity. In the more general, case
on Instagram, using a data

set of about 25 million posts. And this figure shows the
rates of severe content

on Instagram increasing over
time based on our model. And so one of the things that
was really interesting to me

during my PhD was
actually proving you could solve these kind
of technical problems. We can build some models that
deal with these problems.

But as I move forward in my PhD
and got closer to graduation, one of the things that
started really worrying me

were the outcomes
of when we solve these problems of poor models
and making them better, and then actually deploying
them in the real world.

So this is just
like two articles that have come up
in the last year about the use of generative AI
in mental health applications.

The top is when Koko,
which is a chat bot, started generating responses
to people using ChatGPT and not

telling them. Normally, Koko is
done by volunteers who like directly counsel
with you and talk to you.

And people got really
upset that 4,000 people were like being helped by
ChatGPT and nobody told them.

Even if they thought that the
care was actually pretty good. And then we also
have this challenge that AI models that
are built on large data

sets that move beyond
just social networks across the whole
web are actually imitating these
dangerous behaviors

and can be forced in
many ways to come up with these kinds of ideas. And so in these cases, I get
really curious about, OK,

so we can build good models. What are the kinds of things
we might expect them to do, and how might they
behave in the wild?

And I think one of the
challenges with these two is that these are a
little speculative. These are tiny, small
examples of when

ChatGPT and other large language
models running independently may have negative consequences.

But these consequences
aren't just like speculative, like tech imagining
with the fun of ChatGPT.

This is actually an example of a
negative consequence coming out of Amazon's recommender system.

So this is two substances that
when you take them together, you will die. And this is basically--
and I do not

mean this in any
way to be crass. This is a literal click to
buy suicide cocktail that was being propagated
through its systems

because there was a group
online that was going to Amazon and encouraging people to
purchase this pair of symptoms--

a pair of substances. Amazon sees people
continuously buying this. It says, hey, this is a good
recommendation to make to you.

If you buy substance A, you
probably want substance B, too. And this was up on
Amazon for six months

and got reported on by I
think the New York Times twice before it was
actually taken down.

And so these are the
kinds of questions I also wonder about the
consequences of good systems. When we have stuff
that actually works,

how are we actually going to
handle the fact that ChatGPT may behave in ways that are
damaging to people's well-being?

Or when ChatGPT replaces people
in therapy, what do we do? And so all these interesting
ethical questions

come up in this work that
are really important to me as a computer scientist
to both acknowledge,

start thinking about because
I have the technical capacity to do so and to try and solve.

And so this leads
to the big question. You might not be surprised. Like one of the things I'm
really interested in how

you build and evaluate AI
systems for mental health that are actually rigorous and solve
the problem we claim that they

solve, but are also ethical. And think about
people's well-being and their preferences about
how these systems operate

in the wild. So I'm going to show you today
about how my research kind of contributes to
a holistic vision

of human computer
or human-centered AI to solve problems.

And the domain that I focus
on is in mental health and social media. But many of these tools
and techniques and insights

extend beyond just the case of
social media and mental health, given their focus
on sort of socially

contentious sensitive issues. You can imagine a lot
of these same questions about appropriateness of
tools, good tools being

deployed in practice. These come up in areas like
mis and disinformation, and political polarization,
toxicity detection,

and prevention of harassment
in online communities. And sort of the informal
vision of my research

that I like to talk
about when I'm not giving like a very
formal talk is how can I serve humanity and make people's
lives better while also making

some really cool and
impactful tech, too? And this is sort of a
combination of both my interest

personally in making sure the
tech that I build actually is successful and empathetic
and ethical, but also

from my disciplinary background. I have an undergrad in
media studies in comm. And my graduate degrees
are in computer science.

And I feel really impassioned
to combine these two together in human computer
interaction and AI

research such that
we can actually do both at the same time. And my goal with this
talk is to persuade you. You can actually do both as
something like a research career

that you might be interested in. Quick plug for my group. They're the ones who are doing
a lot of this work for me

at this point. We are part of GroupLens at UMN. As Michael explained,
we are an old HCI group

that's been around since
like the late early '90s. I was not at elementary
school by that point.

But they've been doing
groundbreaking research on recommender systems, peer
production, and social media

since the mid '90s. These are my fantastic
PhD students who help me do all of this work.

And they're really interested in
all aspects of human-centered AI for mental health as well as
other stigmatized identities.

Some of them are core AI
researchers like [? Neradine ?] who's at the top left. He's really interested in
building AI tech that works

outside of the global north. Versus some of my other students
do interview work and work on social science theory and
think more about the HCI ethics

side of these problems. And I like to give them a little
shout here because they're the ones who are doing
this work with me now

and are some of the brains
behind my operation. So you'll see
their photos pop up when they're the
ones who are kind

of leading the projects that
I'm going to talk about. So it's an overview of what
I'm going to talk about today. I'm going to deep dive
into this idea about data

set quality error and improving
validity in this conversation. Because I think it's
an important issue

that's sort of emerged
in the last five years. And people really aren't sort
of addressing it in the way that I'm kind of
personally satisfied about.

I'm going to walk you through
kind of a several projects that kind of have queued up the
empirical technical work

that I'm doing, which is sort
of an analytical deep dive into the practices of
the field, empirically showing that my analytical
argument was actually true.

And then the technical
kind of brainstorming that I've been doing about
how to solve these problems. Also talk about some work we're
doing in building and deploying

interventions to help people's
mental health be better. And then I'm going to wrap up
with social outcomes of HCI systems.

One thing I'll just mention. I'm totally happy to take
questions for clarification. But this talk
typically generates

some really spicy and
interesting ethical questions and things that are
like a little bit bigger that can be answered
in like 30 to 45 seconds.

And so if you have
those questions, please write them down. We can totally come
back to the end. This talk is only going to take
me about another 30, 35 minutes.

So we'll have plenty
of time for Q&A later. All right. So today, we're going
to talk-- or I'm going to talk a lot about
dataset quality error

and improving validity. How many of you all
have ever taken an intro to psych or psychology classes?

Some experience in psych? OK. This is actually better
than most of the time when I ask this in a
computer science audience.

You all might be familiar
with this concept of validity, or the idea that the
thing that you're trying to measure actually
aligns with the concept

that you have in
your head about it. This is really
crucial in psychology when we start to
use this to measure

hard to define concepts like
social support, personality. And in clinical psychology,
defining this idea of

and measuring concepts like
depression and anxiety. Now, towards the end
of my PhD, after I

was building all these
systems, I was like, yeah, we can totally predict
these dangerous things from mental health.

I had this kind of
moment of like, wait, am I actually doing
the thing that I said that I'm doing with this work?

And I wanted to go back
and reflect on practices that not only I was engaging in,
but that I was also replicating

from prior work that was
receiving hundreds of citations and driving the development
of these systems

from places like Facebook
and Google behind the scenes. So towards the end
of my PhD, I got

really interested
in how practice affects these decisions in
the papers that I was reading.

So I conducted this gigantic
systematic literature review of research that predicted
mental health via social media

data. Now, this is an ongoing
project that my lab maintains. Currently, we started out with
I think 55 or 60 papers that

was in 2018 or 2019. We got up to 75 papers in
2020, and 129 papers in 2022.

And so this area
is rapidly growing. It's very intriguing, and
it's also a very interesting

interdisciplinary
area where researchers in machine learning, AI, natural
language processing, HCI,

and health informatics which
is a huge threat of work actually start to
contribute to this work.

And so it was really
difficult to actually-- I don't want to
underscore that this is a systematic review
where I just basically read

a lot of papers. Getting this in a
way that actually maps to the idea of what
I had took a lot of time. I'm really happy to talk to you
about systematic reviews in Q

and A if that's something
that you're interested in. But I'm just going to skim the
sort of methodology of this for the sake of this talk.

So as I mentioned
earlier, validity is a really important
concept when you're dealing with these kind
of fuzzy difficult to measure

concepts so in this
particular dataset, we wanted to look at
construct validity which is

a specific form of measurement. This is basically
making inferences from the sampling particulars
of a study to the higher order

constructs of what
they represent. OK, that's like the
textbook definition from like one of the famous
textbooks about measurement.

Let's talk about
what that means. In your head, you have
an idea of a concept you want to measure. Let's say it's depression.

How are you going
to actually know that a person you're screening
in person has depression? Everybody, we probably
need some kind

of agreed on ideas or
notions or variables that might affect depression. And we want to make sure
that those are rigorous.

Construct validity
focuses on that first task that the idea is that
you have in your head actually can map in some
way to the real world,

and those real world ideas
can map it back to the ideas that everybody kind of
holds about this definition

of depression they
have in their head. Now, for my case,
what that means is if we're trying to use social
media to measure depression,

does the social media data
actually represent depression? Or does it represent
another concept?

And you might ask, how
do you measure that? Now, the way that we typically
do this in social media data

is with proxies. Proxies are an alternative
means by measuring a concept when you can't actually ask a
person directly whether or not

they're experiencing the thing
that they're experiencing. Traditionally, you would ask
someone in a clinical interview,

hey, have you been feeling down
and blue for the last two weeks? Have you had a lack of emotions? Are you really angry?

These kind of screening
questions you or a loved 1st may have experienced when
you go to the doctor, and they're talking to you
about your mental health.

We can't do that with social
media users very easily. And even in studies
where we can, it gets prohibitively expensive
to get a large enough dataset

to build a machine learning
model based on that data. So we use proxies instead. And so one of the things
the systematic literature

review found was the kinds
of varieties of proxies that people said mapped to
concepts in mental health.

So they would use things
like computer scientists who would go in and say,
does this person seem like they're depressed?

Yes or no or maybe. They would use community
or network affiliations like participating in a
Reddit subreddit about anxiety

to say that person
would have anxiety or by using hashtags related to
certain behaviors or disorders.

They also would look at things
like personal self disclosures of diagnosis, administering
screeners and questions

to people if they had the
time and resources to, keyword matching. This leaves me with the
question though, OK, you

have these concepts
that you say that you're using to measure mental health. Do they actually
represent mental health?

And I'm sure you're starting
to stew in your mind of like, does everybody who
post to r/depression, are they actually all depressed?

Now, there's a lot
of reasons to believe that those people are having
valid symptoms that are distressing them.

We believe that these people,
when they're posting for help, are actually distressed. But if you care about predicting
the outcome, which is depression

specifically, they may
not all map to that narrow construct of diagnosis.

They may actually, in
fact, have some kinds of anxiety, bipolar disorder
which manifests as depression

for some people over like
short periods of time before they enter
manic episodes. They might also have just
other conditions that

are not related to depression. They may be asking on
behalf of a loved one. It's hard to know from
some of these sources

whether or not they
actually generalize. And so we were like,
well, do people even address this in their arguments? Now, I've talked to you
about the depression example.

But the one that I think
is actually most salient and concerning to me is anxiety. I personally have anxiety.

And it's something
that I have to manage through therapeutic processes.

But when I was
looking at papers that were talking about predicting
anxiety, none of them specified what they
meant when they

said anxiety, which
as somebody who has a clinical disorder of
this was like, wait, wait,

wait, wait, wait. You don't even tell me
how you predict this? You're not telling me
how you set this up? Because anxiety can
be a symptom that

influences both some
anxious trends, but also other mental disorders like OCD.

It can be a transient emotion
that people experience. I'm a little more
anxious than normal because I'm giving a talk.

It can also be lay usage
when you have a friend that you might refer to, like,
man, she's just like anxious. Don't worry about it.

Or it can actually be a
category of nervous disorders of which generalized
anxiety disorder is

one of several different
kinds of anxiety disorders. Nobody in these
papers mapped the fact

that hashtag anxiety
could map to any of these four definitions. And you can imagine
people using hashtags

in different circumstances
to talk about all four of these different examples. And what we found was
that nobody actually

defined what they meant by
anxiety when they measured it from the data. And this was true
across the vast majority

of studies of mental illness
and machine learning. Now, this was in 2019. We've repeated and looked at
these results in the future,

and we still find
similar things. And the challenge here
is like if nobody defines

what they mean by anxiety,
and they say they're actually predicting this outcome,
it's really hard to know if the system that
they've built actually

works to predict the thing
that they care about. And what we did is
in follow up work, we actually looked at whether
or not these kinds of practices

were actually happening
across more papers. And we looked at
sort of practices related to disclosing data
source, the kind of information

we need. And what we found
is-- this is in 2023. We actually showed that
these practices are becoming

more normatively implicit. Basically that when disclosure
happens across groups of papers,

people in the future
will start to do the same kind of disclosures
and replicate prior work. Now, this is really
good when you

have things like IRB disclosures
and consent and anonymizing people correctly in
datasets to make sure

that their data does not leak
into other kinds of models. But this actually can be
really, really damaging

if practices of a
lack of disclosure are not getting reported. And people believe that not
reporting on information

is something that's
standard in the field. Now, one of the things-- so
this is kind of good news.

We have this
practice where people are like more and more reporting
on different ethical practices. Unfortunately, like the
data sourcing and inclusion

are being reported more. But unfortunately,
people still didn't buy the risks of
this argument that I

was making from the
analytical kind of analysis that I did in the
systematic lit review. Now, I just want to be clear. These are paraphrased
and slightly

editorialized comments I
found about the findings that I just told you about. But people have sincerely
told me these things that

may be like, well,
it doesn't actually matter if the concept
measures the thing that you claim it measures. Our performance doesn't lie.

We're getting F1 of like
0.91, 0.95 with like accuracy that's super high.

And like some people were
like, but LLMs will just like solve this problem. If you just shove it into
[? BERT, ?] I literally got

this in a paper review. If you just put it into
[? BERT, ?] it would be fine. And then the other
one was like it's the best data that we can get.

Give me a break. I'm trying to solve a
really hard social problem. I should have the flexibility
of possibly that data making

these errors. Now, I have feelings about
this, unsurprisingly. And this leads me to this
interesting question of whether

or not when we use like complex
machine learning architectures like LLMs or BERT or other
kind of transformers,

we actually can erase
the problems of the data. And so these arguments
were basically running against
the classic notion

that we teach in
like computer science 101 which is garbage
in garbage out. That the quality of the data
that you put into a system

necessarily affects the
quality of the inferences and the outcomes that it gives.

And these comments were not
just levied in reviews, but also in job talks where people were
like, no, it's totally fine.

Just like throw an
LLM at it, Stevie. It'll be totally fine. So I was like, all right. Hold on.

I got this. So I actually got
really, really annoyed and wanted to prove empirically
that this downstream process

actually mattered
so that people would by the empirical consequences
of this bad data actually

affected the bottles themselves. So what we did is we looked at
one of the most popular and sort of clinically gold
standard proxy signals

which is diagnostic
self-disclosure. This is when people
go online and say,

I have been diagnosed
with a specific disorder. Now, the reason we
love this disclosure is because people are almost
always honest about it.

Mental health is stigmatized,
and it can take a lot for people to admit when they go through
stigmatizing or shameful

experiences. Side note, I don't think
that mental health should be stigmatized, but
it still is something.

And so we look for
people when they talk online that says I
was diagnosed with bulimia. And we know that this is
a high quality signal.

So let me show you how the
inference like typically goes in the machine
learning process. So we want to be able to find
people with eating disorders

in the whole world because
they're often undertreated, underdiagnosed. Eating disorders are
very dangerous when

they go unchecked. We then say, OK, we know
that we can get people with a diagnosed
eating disorder.

And then we look at people
who disclose eating disorders in social media data.

We then can get
this data from lots of different sources including
Twitter and Facebook and TikTok

because people
will disclose this. And then we get
our training data which is that shaded
area in the middle. And then we can use that
training data as info

to be able to infer back to
at least the blue circle. But our goal is to
actually infer back

to the whole purple circle. And that we've built
a model because we know these people have
an eating disorder,

we can generalize this back
to find other people in purple that aren't in the blue circle. And this is a kind of
common setup in these papers

where the idea is like, you
can't get the data directly so we use the social media
data and then generalize it.

And this goes to
the problem of what I was mentioning earlier if
people being like, the data will just be fine. And me being like,
wait, wait, wait,

we don't know that this actually
measures the purple circle. So this project was an audit
to show that you could actually

measure the purple circle. So the question that
we looked at was, are these gaps caused by the way
that the field operationalizes

the training data into
the models themselves? And do gaps come up in
the validity and integrity

of those models? Yes, they are very
hard to detect though because it's
easy to cover up

their gaps with high
technical performance which gets to the point that
person was criticizing

my work from previously of,
well, the model performs fine. Clearly, it's working well. And we do this through an audit
that the training data actually

has really damaging contextual
gaps that compromise the validity of the model. And so let me walk you through
how we got this data, how

we ran our little audit,
and one of the examples of these contextual gaps
so that you understand kind of the problems that we get
when we do this like training

data inference. So as I mentioned,
self-disclosure is one of the most common ones.

And part of the
reason it's so loved is because you can build
a regular expression to get it very, very quickly. So we modified and basically
improved on state-of-the-art

regular expressions that
are used to find this data. For those of you that
have never used regex,

it's a really, really nice open
kind of flexible string matching protocol where you can set
up very loose string matches

to be able to find
people like text matches. So it's really good for finding
and identifying repetitive text

like phone numbers and emails. And you can leverage
it to look up, "I was diagnosed with bulimia."

And that's exactly what we did. We came up with self
references of saying that it was me who was
diagnosed, variants

of the way that you
could say diagnosed in the English language. And then a list of
disorders and slang terms

that people use
to refer to being diagnosed with those disorders. So "ana" and "an" is
anorexia or anorexia nervosa

so "an," "bn" in
bulimia, "osfed" in ED are sort of the general
on all encompassing

terms for eating disorders. And we were able to do
this multi round refinement on the regular expression with
human labeling to make sure

that the quality of these the
regular expression matches were actually very high quality. So we went in did probably
a process of five or six

iterations on this to
make sure it was perfect. And then we went through
and did a human annotation and got an F1 of about 0.85.

Now, what's interesting
here that I don't report on specifically with the table is,
typically, regular expressions

are a high precision activity. Our precision and recall trade
off for this F1 was a lot

tighter than the
state-of-the-art baselines which means that we had less false
negatives than other people who

had implemented this. Meaning that we could trust that
our regular expression was not pulling in erroneous data
when it made these matches.

So we looked at the
self disclosures and said, yes, these
are all people talking about being diagnosed.

We're really, really
confident of that. Then what we did is we set up
a machine learning experiment

to see if these problems that we
had in our head about validity actually propagated
through these models.

So what we did is we
took a dataset of posts from a Reddit community. I've anonymized
it to r/communED.

It's an eating disorder
support subreddit that gives people a neutral
space to talk about disorder

and doesn't allow
for content that would be sort of
pro or advocating for disordered eating behaviors.

Of the training data,
we found 292 users who had a diagnostic disclosure
inside this community.

More on that number in a second. And to match the field
sort of testing protocols, we found historical data
from 292 random users

with no diagnostic disclosure. Now, we selected this
kind of random baseline from the same community to
make the prediction task

kind of artificially harder. If your goal is to check the
validity of the disclosure, you want to test this against
the possibly closest community

of negative results which
would be people talking at an eating disorder community
that have never said that they

have an eating disorder. And then the reason that we
want this is because then we have high confidence
that a model that

can make these distinguishing
characteristics is actually honing in on
people we have high confidence

have a diagnosis, which is
that clinical certitude we want to replicate in the model.
